Description: Egyptian discus lamp with glossy brown-red slip. Ovule pattern on rim, figure of lion in relief on discus. Remains of broken pierced vertical handle. Fine, but overfired (reduced) orange-grey fabric.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels in the British Museum include ovule patterning and animal subjects on earlier 75AD to 200AD handle-less lamps (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, Q2014, to Q2017) and ovule patterning on the same 2nd century AD handled lamp type (Bailey 1988, Lamps III, Q2031). Parallels of this form from Mons Claudianus were found in deposits dated to the Antonine period of the 2nd century AD (Knowles 2006, Type, nos 135-141). Roman Ehnasya parallel (Petrie1905, 5, pl. 53) cited on Philadelphia register card. Possibly imported fabric. Knowles, K. 2006. The pottery lamps. In V.A.Maxfield and D.P.S. Peacock, Survey and excavation at Mons Claudianus 1987-1993. Vol.3 Ceramic vessels and related objects. IFAO Cairo. 309–426. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905. Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.23) (Phase 1)
